questions.questionText: The dog was so famished after the long walk that it ate three bowls of food. What does "famished" mean?
questions.explanation: The context clue 'ate three bowls of food' tells us the dog was very hungry. 'Famished' means extremely hungry or starving.

questions.questionText: Which word is an antonym (opposite) of "enormous"?
questions.explanation: An antonym is a word with the opposite meaning. 'Enormous' means very large, so its opposite is 'tiny,' which means very small. The other choices (huge, giant, large) are all synonyms of enormous.

questions.questionText: The prefix "un-" means "not." What does the word "unfamiliar" mean?
questions.explanation: The prefix 'un-' means 'not.' When added to 'familiar' (meaning known or recognized), it creates 'unfamiliar,' which means not known or not recognized.

questions.questionText: The teacher commended the students for their excellent work on the science project. What does "commended" mean?
questions.explanation: The context clue 'for their excellent work' suggests the teacher had a positive reaction. 'Commended' means praised or expressed approval.

questions.questionText: Read this sentence: "The pitcher threw the ball to first base." What does "pitcher" mean in this sentence?

choices.label: B
choices.text: A baseball player who throws the ball

questions.explanation: The word 'pitcher' has multiple meanings. In this sentence, the context clues 'threw the ball' and 'first base' tell us the sentence is about baseball, so 'pitcher' means the player who throws the ball.

questions.questionText: Despite the team's initial reluctance, they eventually embraced the new strategy and it led to their victory. What does "reluctance" mean?
questions.explanation: The word 'despite' signals a contrast — the team was reluctant at first but 'eventually embraced' the strategy. This contrast tells us that 'reluctance' means the opposite of embracing something: unwillingness or hesitation.

questions.questionText: The suffix "-ous" means "full of." Which word means "full of danger"?
questions.explanation: Adding the suffix '-ous' (meaning 'full of') to 'danger' creates 'dangerous,' which means full of danger. 'Endangered' uses a different prefix/suffix pattern, 'dangerously' is an adverb, and 'danger' is the base noun.

questions.questionText: The ancient ruins were a testament to the ingenuity of the civilization that built them. What does "ingenuity" mean?
questions.explanation: The sentence describes ancient ruins as a 'testament' (proof) of the builders' qualities. 'Ingenuity' means cleverness, creative ability, or inventive skill — the quality that allows people to design and build impressive structures.
